content: We can define a fibered profunctor the same way: over each heteromorphism, a conjoint.

Let A,B\mathbb{A}, \mathbb{B}A,B be fibrations, and R0:A0→B0R_0:\mathbb{A}_0\to \mathbb{B}_0R0​:A0​→B0​ be a profunctor of base categories. Define a fibered profunctor over R0R_0R0​ to be a profunctor R:A→BR:\mathbb{A}\to \mathbb{B}R:A→B with a transformation R⇒R0R\Rightarrow R_0R⇒R0​ so that the collage is a fibration.
preimg-trans.png fibprof-cart.png
Similarly, a fibered transformation is a commuting square of transformations so that the collage is a fibered functor.
This defines the double category Fib\mathrm{Fib}Fib of fibered categories and functors, fibered profunctors and transformations.
One might hope that this is a fibrant double category, a.k.a. an equipment; but no: there are conjoints, but not companions.
The reason boils down to the fact that fibered categories and fibered profunctors are really "indexed conjoints". I'll draw a picture to show the problem.
fib-no-comp.png

Let f:A→Bf:\mathbb{A}\to\mathbb{B}f:A→B be a fibered functor, and consider the companions B0(f0,1):A0→B0\mathbb{B}_0(f_0,1):\mathbb{A}_0\to \mathbb{B}_0B0​(f0​,1):A0​→B0​ and B(f,1):A→B\mathbb{B}(f,1):\mathbb{A}\to \mathbb{B}B(f,1):A→B. Let ϕ:B0(f0A0,B0)\phi: \mathbb{B}_0(f_0A_0,B_0)ϕ:B0​(f0​A0​,B0​) be an element of the base profunctor, and BBB be in the fiber over B0B_0B0​.
Is there a "cartesian element" of B(f,1)\mathbb{B}(f,1)B(f,1) over ϕ\phiϕ?
There is a perfectly good cartesian morphism ϕ∗B→B\phi^\ast B\to Bϕ∗B→B, but this is in B\mathbb{B}B, not the companion B(f,1)\mathbb{B}(f,1)B(f,1).
There is no reason to expect that the cartesian morphism is of the form fA→BfA\to BfA→B.
This is a basic obstruction; extra properties of the functor or the fibrations do not help.
So, Fib\mathrm{Fib}Fib has conjoints but not companions. (And dually, opFib\mathrm{opFib}opFib has companions but not conjoints.)
(All thoughts welcome.)

If you want an equipment of fibred categories, I expect you need to restrict to categories fibred over a specific category, rather than allowing the base to vary (like how one usually considers Cat(E)\textrm{Cat}(\mathcal E)Cat(E) for a specific E\mathcal EE). But I'm guessing there's a reason you've chosen not to do it that way?
Hm okay, well why do you think fixing the base could help?

The motivation: a fibrant double category is a category C0\mathbb{C}_0C0​ with a fibration C→C02\mathbb{C}\to \mathbb{C}_0^2C→C02​. I'm constructing the triple category FDC\mathrm{FDC}FDC, and it should be fibrant: a double functor should have both a companion and a conjoint.
I don't think that fixing the base would help, but I need to draw it out.

Yeah, I think it doesn't change the problem. In that picture "fib-no-comp" above, even if the bottom profunctor is the hom of a fixed base, there's still no reason to expect the cartesian morphism to be of the form fA→BfA\to BfA→B.

Christian Williams said:

Hm okay, well why do you think fixing the base could help?

It's known that S\mathcal SS-indexed categories form a Yoneda structure: see, for instance, §6 of Conspectus of variable categories, hence an equipment.
Oh great thanks, I hadn't found any literature like this. So what is the notion of fibered profunctor" here...
Oh, this is different. This is two-sided fibrations, i.e. pseudofunctors Aop×B→CatA^{op}\times B\to \mathrm{Cat}Aop×B→Cat.
These are bimodules, loose morphisms in a fibrant double category. I'm talking about a double category in which fibered categories are objects.
Anyway, this thread is for any thoughts about: the concept of profunctor between fibered categories, and their formal theory.
If fibred categories have conjoints and opfibered categories have companions, do bifibred categories have both (so form a fibrant double category) ?

Christian Williams said:

These are bimodules, loose morphisms in a fibrant double category. I'm talking about a double category in which fibered categories are objects.

The objects of the Yoneda structure in that paper are indexed categories, i.e. (up to equivalence) fibred categories. I haven't looked at the paper for a while, but I would have expected the proarrows to be indexed profunctors.

That's what I hoped! But then I realized no, bifibrations don't change the problem --- there's still no reason for the cartesian morphism ϕ∗(B)→B\phi^\ast(B)\to Bϕ∗(B)→B to be of the form fA→BfA\to BfA→B.
Ah okay, I need to look at that paper more closely.

Wow, I forgot --- of course fibrations are monads; they're categories in [Cop,Set][C^{op},\mathrm{Set}][Cop,Set]. So yes, Fib(C)\mathrm{Fib}(C)Fib(C) is an equipment, and I'll be working to understand those bimodules.
So yes, I see what you were saying about a fixed base. But I think the difficulty is in changing base along a profunctor.

So for Street, a profunctor in Fib(I)\mathrm{Fib}(\mathbb{I})Fib(I) R:A→BR:\mathbb{A}\to \mathbb{B}R:A→B of fibrations over I\mathbb{I}I gives for each object I:II:\mathbb{I}I:I a profunctor between fibers RI:AI→BIR_I:\mathbb{A}_I\to \mathbb{B}_IRI​:AI​→BI​, and for each morphism f:I→Jf:I\to Jf:I→J a reindexing transformation RJ⇒RI(Af,Bf)R_J\Rightarrow R_I(\mathbb{A}_f,\mathbb{B}_f)RJ​⇒RI​(Af​,Bf​).
So for each fixed object, it gives an arbitrary profunctor between fibers, "functorially" with respect to base morphisms.

Whereas the definition I propose above, there is a profunctor between base categories Q0:X→YQ_0:\mathbb{X}\to \mathbb{Y}Q0​:X→Y, and over each heteromorphism q:Q0(X,Y)q:Q_0(X,Y)q:Q0​(X,Y) a conjoint Q(q)≃AX(1,q∗):AX→BYQ(q)\simeq \mathbb{A}_X(1,q^\ast):\mathbb{A}_X\to \mathbb{B}_YQ(q)≃AX​(1,q∗):AX​→BY​.

Okay, I think I'm seeing the bigger picture. Street's equipments Fib(I) are slices over a fixed base Fib/I, but Fib itself is a collage over all of Cat, over both functors and profunctors. Being fibered over an identity profunctor is very special (hence forming an equipment), but the more general notion of fibered profunctor must be defined purely in terms of heteromorphisms.

That leads to this simple characterization via collage of a transformation. Yet it also leads to this obstacle with companions, above.

So I think the double category of all fibrations has only conjoints, because ultimately, both fibered categories and profunctors are just (matrices of families of) conjoints.
What if we just collage opFib, BiFib, and Fib all together?
08ff21b6-644a-4095-96fd-97e424c08722.jpg
(deleted)
Companions on the left, conjoints on the right: so this double category is not fibrant but rather a "two-sided fibration" (2-profunctor) from left to right.

I think there is a double profunctor from opFib to Fib, which gives categories of bifibered profunctors and transformations.

and I am thinking of its collage.

Ah, but a bifibered profunctor composed with a fibered one is only fibered - so the left and right act on the middle, not vice versa. So it's not a profunctor from opFib to Fib.

And yet I think the "collage" is a perfectly nice double category! Things just "tend to flow outward" horizontally - a bifibration in the middle will go either to the "left double cat" opFib or the right Fib as soon as you compose on the left or right.
